question: What state of matter forms when a star’s high temperature pulls electrons away from atoms?

content.source_1: Plasma is the state of matter in which atoms are ionized—electrons are free from nuclei—and the charged particles exhibit collective electromagnetic behavior.
content.source_2: The temperatures in hot, luminous stars (e.g., O- and B-type) are high enough to strip electrons from atoms, producing extensive ionization.
content.source_3: Under such ionizing stellar conditions, matter exists predominantly as an ionized gas (plasma) in ordinary stellar atmospheres and interiors.
content.source_4: In the dense interiors of white dwarfs, matter is fully ionized (electrons unbound), yet at sufficiently high density and moderate temperature the ions can form a Coulomb crystal: a solid lattice immersed in a degenerate electron sea.
content.source_5: Observations and models show that many white dwarf cores crystallize as they cool—releasing latent heat—so their cores become solid despite the material remaining fully ionized.
content.source_6: White dwarfs are extremely hot stellar remnants (surface temperatures up to ~100,000 K), so they qualify as hot stars while their interiors can be crystallized solids under the conditions described.
